questions.text: A patient has mental retardation, seizures, thrombotic state, amino acid metabolism disorder, osteoporosis, and ectopia lentis. Which vitamin must be supplemented to the patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

The clinical presentation, including mental retardation, seizures, a thrombotic state, osteoporosis, and ectopia lentis, is characteristic of homocystinuria.

 

Homocystinuria is a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS), an enzyme involved in methionine metabolism. This deficiency leads to an accumulation of homocysteine, which can cause a wide range of symptoms, including neurodevelopmental issues, skeletal abnormalities, and vascular complications.

 

Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is crucial in the management of homocystinuria, as it is a cofactor for CBS. Supplementation with vitamin B6 can enhance the activity of the residual enzyme, helping to reduce homocysteine levels in responsive patients, thus mitigating the symptoms and reducing the risk of complications such as thrombosis.

 

Note –

 

The causes of ectopia lentis include several conditions, such as Marfan's syndrome, homocystinuria, Weill-Marchesani syndrome, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. These are important to remember when identifying the underlying cause of lens dislocation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: While vitamin B12 is also involved in homocysteine metabolism, deficiencies in B12 are not directly related to the presentation seen in homocystinuria. B12 supplementation is more relevant to other conditions such as pernicious anemia or when correcting elevated homocysteine due to B12 deficiency, but it is not the primary treatment for homocystinuria.

 

Option C. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) is not involved in the metabolic pathway of homocysteine. It plays a role in carbohydrate metabolism and is associated with conditions like Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and beriberi but not with homocystinuria.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is not directly related to the symptoms of homocystinuria or the management of this disorder. It is mainly involved in energy production and the metabolism of fats, drugs, and steroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homocystinuria is characterized by ectopia lentis, thrombotic state, mental retardation, and seizures, among other features. Vitamin B6 supplementation is essential in managing this condition by aiding the function of the deficient enzyme cystathionine beta-synthase.

questions.text: The 27-year-old patient arrives with a complaint of diminution of vision and painful ocular movements, following a history of trauma. On examination, the pupils are non-reactive. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Optic neuritis

 

Traumatic injury at eyebrows may damage the optic nerve, leading to optic neuritis.

 

OPTIC NEURITIS

 

  • It is a pathological condition of optic nerve where nerve impulse is impaired.
  • It includes inflammatory and demyelinating disorders of the optic nerve.
  • Most common cause of optic neuritis is multiple sclerosis.
  • The clinical features are as follows:
  • Symptoms 
    • Sudden profound painful loss of vision in one eye
    • Pain with ocular movements (aggravated with upward movement)
    • Color vision impairment usually affects red and green color (in contrast macular lesions produce blue yellow color defects)
    • Depth perception of moving objects is impaired (Pulfrich phenomenon)
  • Signs 
    • Earliest sign is Marcus Gunn pupil present with relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
    • Tenderness at insertion of medial and superior rectus.
    • The most characteristic feature is optic disc edema
    • Visual field changes include relative central or centrocaecal scotoma.

 

 

  • Management:

Intravenous methyl prednisolone. Steroids reduce the period of visual loss without having any effect on the final visual recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataract: Cataracts cause gradual, painless loss of vision due to clouding of the lens and are not associated with painful ocular movements or non-reactive pupils.

 

Option C. Glaucoma: Acute angle-closure glaucoma can cause painful vision loss but is associated with a red eye, elevated intraocular pressure, and a mid-dilated non-reactive pupil rather than non-reactive pupils from trauma.

 

Option D. Papilledema: This is swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure, typically presenting with headache, transient visual obscurations, and bilateral disc swelling, not specifically associated with painful ocular movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic neuritis, especially following trauma, can present with painful vision loss, impaired color vision, and a relative afferent pupillary defect. It is characterized by optic disc edema and managed with intravenous steroids to reduce the duration of visual loss.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below:(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Entropion

 

The image shows a condition where the lower eyelid is turned inward, causing the eyelashes to rub against the cornea. This condition is known as entropion. Entropion is characterized by the inward rolling of the eyelid, which can lead to irritation, pain, and potential damage to the cornea due to the constant friction of the eyelashes.

 

Key Features of Entropion:

 

  • Inward rolling of the eyelid: This is the hallmark of entropion, leading to eyelashes brushing against the cornea.
  • Symptoms: Patients may experience discomfort, foreign body sensation, tearing, redness, and in severe cases, corneal abrasions or ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ectropion: This condition involves the outward turning of the eyelid, which can cause exposure and drying of the cornea. It does not match the image as there is no outward turning observed.

 

Option C. Distichiasis: This condition is characterized by an extra row of eyelashes growing from the meibomian glands, which can sometimes cause irritation if they grow inward. However, the entire eyelid does not roll inward in distichiasis.

 

Option D. Trichiasis: This refers to the misdirection of eyelashes, where the eyelashes turn inward and irritate the cornea, but the eyelid itself remains in its normal position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entropion is the inward rolling of the eyelid, causing the eyelashes to rub against the cornea, leading to irritation and potential damage. This is different from ectropion, where the eyelid turns outward, and from trichiasis and distichiasis, where only the eyelashes are misdirected.

questions.text: A young patient with a history of contact lens use presents with foreign body sensation, and watery discharge. On examination, the following finding is observed. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis

 

Giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC)

 

  • It is also called contact lens–induced papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC).
  • It refers to a specific type of allergic inflammation affecting the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Etiology: It usually occurs due to soft hydrophilic contact lens use, protruding suture ends, ocular prostheses or rarely after many years of rigid contact lens use. The underlying mechanism is a hypersensitivity reaction (types I and IV).
  • Symptoms: Itching, watering, foreign body sensation and, occasionally, blurring of vision.
  • Signs: Conjunctival congestion, predominantly in the upper palpebral region with large polygonal papillae on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Macropapillae are 0.3–1.0 mm in size, and giant papillae are 1–2 mm in size.
  • Management:
    1. Discontinuing the use of soft contact lenses, removal of offending sutures, cleaning and polishing of any ocular prosthesis and replacing it with one coated with biocompatible material such as Biocoat.
    2. Useful ancillary therapy includes mast cell stabilizers (lodoxamide, cromolyn sodium or olopatadine), along with artificial tears, antihistaminic drops and decongestants.
    3. Topical steroids can be administered for a short while and a subtarsal injection of long-acting steroid may be needed in severe cases, provided that the patient is not a steroid responder.

 

Characteristics of vernal keratoconjunctivitis:

 

Vernal conjunctivitis (vernal keratoconjunctivitis or spring catarrh)

  • This is a recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis occurring with the onset of summer, rather than spring.
  • Found in young children and adolescents, usually boys.
  • Chief symptoms: Burning, itching, some photophobia and lacrimation.
  • Two typical forms:
    1. The palpebral form
      • Easily recognized on everting the upper lid.
      • The palpebral (upper and lower) conjunctiva is seen to be hypertrophied and mapped out into polygonal raised areas with a milky hue, not unlike cobblestones.
      • The type of patients, the milky hue, freedom of the fornix from implication and the characteristic recurrence in hot weather will usually prevent misdiagnosis.
    2. The limbal or bulbar form.
      • Characteristic feature: Horner–Trantas dots, white dots of eosinophils and epithelial debris at the limbus.
    3. Mixed form: Both may occur together.
  • Both types are complicated by a fine diffuse superficial punctate keratitis.
  • The ultimate prognosis:
    • Children usually have a self-limited disease, over a period of 5–10 years.
    • Some young adults develop more severe manifestations of the disease (dry eye, shield ulcer), with indefinite recurrences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corneal abrasion: Characterized by a scratch or injury to the cornea, typically presenting with pain, redness, and tearing, but without the characteristic large papillae seen in GPC.

 

Option B. Vernal keratoconjunctivitis: A recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis occurring with the onset of summer, commonly found in young boys. It presents with burning, itching, photophobia, and lacrimation. The palpebral form shows hypertrophied conjunctiva with a milky hue and cobblestone appearance, while the limbal form presents with Horner-Trantas dots at the limbus.

 

Option D. Keratitis: Inflammation of the cornea, which can present with pain, redness, and visual disturbances, but it does not present with the large papillae characteristic of GPC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis (GPC) is characterized by large papillae on the superior tarsal conjunctiva, typically associated with contact lens use. It presents with itching, watering, and foreign body sensation. Management involves discontinuing the use of contact lenses, using mast cell stabilizers, and in some cases, short-term use of topical steroids.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy gets punched in the eye and the next day he developed diplopia with upward gaze. There is no congestion or proptosis of eye. What is the probable diagnosis?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture floor of orbit

 

A blow out fracture of the orbital floor is caused by sudden increase in orbital pressure due to trauma.

 

Signs:

 

  • Enophthalmos- due to inward displacement of intraorbital contents
  • Diplopia – due to extra ocular muscle (inferior rectus) entrapment in fracture
  • Infra orbital anesthesia- if fracture involves infra orbital canal through which infra orbital nerve passes.
  • Others- periorbital edema, ecchymosis, subcutaneous emphysema, etc

 

Plain X-Ray: Water’s view is the best.

 

On CT: Tear drop sign due to protrusion of orbital fat or inferior rectus muscle into maxillary sinus.

 

Most common wall to be fractured in blow-out fractures is the floor.   

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fracture roof of orbit: This would likely result in different symptoms, such as more significant pain, possible CSF leak, or symptoms indicative of frontal lobe damage. It is less likely to cause diplopia with upward gaze.

 

Option C. Intracranial hemorrhage: This would present with signs of increased intracranial pressure, altered mental status, severe headache, and other neurological deficits. Diplopia without proptosis or congestion is not typical.

 

Option D. Subdural hematoma: This condition would present with neurological symptoms such as headache, confusion, vomiting, and possibly loss of consciousness. Diplopia with upward gaze is not a characteristic symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blow-out fracture of the orbital floor is commonly associated with diplopia with upward gaze due to entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle, enophthalmos, and infraorbital anesthesia.

choices.text: Pain in the area of distribution of 5th nerve

questions.text: Trotter’s triad includes all except?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retroorbital pain

 

Retroorbital pain is not a component of Trotter’s triad. This pain is usually associated with other conditions affecting the orbit or nearby structures but is not typically seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma involving the structures noted in Trotter’s triad.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conductive hearing loss: Part of Trotter’s triad, caused by Eustachian tube obstruction, leading to fluid accumulation in the middle ear.

 

Option C. Palatal palsy: Part of Trotter’s triad, caused by involvement of the vagus nerve, leads to paralysis of the palatal muscles.

 

Option D. Pain in the area of distribution of the 5th nerve: Part of Trotter’s triad, presenting as trigeminal neuralgia due to trigeminal nerve involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trotter’s triad:

  • Trotter’s triad is a set of clinical signs associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. This triad is indicative of the tumor's involvement with specific anatomical structures in the nasopharynx and nearby areas.
  • It includes: 
    • Ipsilateral serous otitis media with conductive hearing loss.
    • Ipsilateral 5th cranial nerve involvement presenting as trigeminal neuralgia.
    • 10th nerve Involvement presenting as palatal palsy.

choices.text: Increase in the size of capsule covering the diameter

questions.text: Which of the following factors should be kept in mind while placing intraocular lens in a child?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Myopic shift

 

Children have a hypermetropic eye ball. The axial length of the eye ball increases as the child grows, resulting in myopic shift. Therefore, power of the intraocular lens is under corrected to compensate for the myopic shift as follows:

 

  1. <2 years of age: 80% of IOL power (i.e. reduce IOL power by 20%)
  2. 2-8 years of age: 90% of IOL power (i.e. reduce IOL power by 10%)
  3. >8 years: 100% of IOL power (use normal calculated IOL power)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypermetropic shift: This is incorrect because the shift observed as children grow is towards myopia, not hypermetropia.

 

Option B. Increase the length of capsule: This option is incorrect as it is not a factor directly related to the placement of the IOL. The axial length of the eye increases naturally as the child grows, not the length of the capsule.

 

Option C. Increase in the size of capsule covering the diameter: This option is also incorrect. While the overall growth of the eye affects the axial length, it is the myopic shift that is the critical factor to consider when determining the power of the IOL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When placing intraocular lenses in children, it is essential to undercorrect the lens power to accommodate for the expected myopic shift as the child grows.

questions.text: A farmer presents with the complaints of pain, photophobia and watering from the eyes. On examination, a corneal ulcer is seen as shown in the figure. Which characteristic associated finding is seen in the image?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Satellite lesions

 

Lesions shown are satellite lesions seen in the fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Fungal Keratitis

 

  • Fusarium and Aspergillus fumigatus are the most common causes around the world, while candida is the most common cause in temperate regions.

 

 

Predisposing Factors

 

  • Injury by vegetative materials or animal tail—most common
  • Long-term use of topical steroids or antibiotics
  • Prior corneal transplantation
  • Contact lens wear
  • Diabetes mellitus.

 

 

Clinical Features

 

  • Symptoms are mild as compared to the signs.
  • Mild pain, watering and photophobia are seen, but ciliary and conjunctival congestion are marked.
  • Characteristic features of corneal ulcer are—dry looking, grayish white with elevated rolled out margins and feathery finger-like extensions into surrounding stroma under intact epithelium, with satellite nodules.
  • A sterile immune ring of Wessely is seen where fungal antigen and host antibody meet.
  • Hypopyon is seen, which is often large and unsterile (pseudohypopyon) as fungi can penetrate into anterior chamber without perforation.

 

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Examination of wet KOH mount, calcofluor white for fungal hyphae and culture on Sabouraud’s medium.

 

 

Treatment

 

  • Natamycin and amphotericin B are the 1st line drugs.
  • Imidazole and flucytosine are used in candida infection.
  • Cycloplegics as atropine or scopolamine are used to reduce ciliary spasm, uveal inflammation and prevent posterior synechiae formation.
  • Anti-inflammatory and analgesics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypopyon: Although hypopyon is seen in fungal keratitis, it is not the characteristic finding associated with the image provided. The primary feature shown in the image is satellite lesions.

 

Option C. Dendrite ulcer: This is characteristic of herpes simplex virus keratitis and presents as branching linear lesions, which is not shown in the image.

 

Option D. Ring infiltrate: This can be seen in some corneal infections but is not the characteristic feature shown in this particular image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fungal keratitis is characterized by satellite lesions, dry-looking ulcers with elevated, rolled-out margins, and feathery extensions. These features help differentiate it from other types of corneal ulcers and guide appropriate management.

questions.text: A patient presented with redness and extreme pain in the eye. There is also diminution of vision and discharge after the use of contact lenses. Which organism can be the causative agent here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acanthamoeba

 

Acanthamoeba is a protozoan that commonly infects the cornea, particularly in individuals who misuse contact lenses. It is characterized by severe pain that is disproportionate to the clinical signs observed. This is due to the organism’s tendency to infiltrate perineurally, causing intense pain by involving the corneal nerves.

 

Acanthamoeba keratitis often presents with a ring-shaped corneal ulcer, which is a key diagnostic feature.

 

 

The culture medium is non-nutrient agar enriched with E. coli.

 

The condition is serious and can lead to severe visual impairment if not treated promptly with appropriate anti-amoebic medications such as Polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) or Propamidine isethionate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Listeria: Listeria primarily causes systemic infections and is not typically associated with eye infections or contact lens misuse. It is a less common cause of keratitis and does not present with the severe pain characteristic of Acanthamoeba.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of bacterial keratitis, often presenting with redness, discharge, and visual impairment. However, it does not cause the extreme pain seen in Acanthamoeba infections, as it does not infiltrate nerves.

 

 

Option D. Streptococcus pyogenes: Streptococcus pyogenes is a bacterial pathogen that can cause various infections but is not commonly associated with severe pain and the distinct ring-shaped ulcer seen in Acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Acanthamoeba keratitis is characterized by severe pain that exceeds clinical findings and is often associated with contact lens misuse, presenting with a distinctive ring-shaped corneal ulcer.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient complains of a nodular lesion near the limbus as shown, with mild discomfort that resolves after treatment with the use of a topical drug. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Episcleritis with Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

Episcleritis is an inflammatory condition affecting the episclera, the layer of tissue lying between the conjunctiva and the sclera. It often presents with a red, nodular lesion near the limbus that causes mild discomfort and responds well to topical treatment, such as phenylephrine, which is a vasoconstrictor. Phenylephrine helps blanch the inflamed vessels, reducing symptoms and improving the appearance of the lesion. Episcleritis is often associated with autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scleritis with Rheumatoid Arthritis: Scleritis involves deeper inflammation of the sclera and is much more painful compared to episcleritis. It does not resolve with topical treatment alone and often requires systemic therapy. This does not match the scenario of mild discomfort and resolution with topical drugs.

 

Option C. Pinguecula and Dry Eye: Pinguecula is a yellowish, elastotic degeneration of the conjunctiva that typically appears as a quiet, non-inflamed lesion. It does not cause significant discomfort or redness, making this an unlikely diagnosis in the presence of nodular inflammation.

 

 

Option D. Pterygium and Astigmatism: Pterygium is characterized by a wing-shaped growth of conjunctiva that extends onto the cornea, causing astigmatism. Since the lesion in question does not encroach onto the cornea, pterygium is not a suitable diagnosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Episcleritis presents as a mildly uncomfortable, nodular lesion near the limbus that responds to topical treatment, such as phenylephrine, and is often associated with autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A child presented with leukocoria and an intraocular mass. On microscopic examination, Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes with scanty cytoplasm were seen. The mass was also positive for synaptophysin. The diagnosis can be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

The correct answer is Retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina typically seen in children, presenting with symptoms such as leukocoria (white reflex in the eye) and an intraocular mass. On microscopic examination, Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, which are characteristic circular arrangements of tumor cells around a central lumen, are seen. These rosettes are a hallmark of well-differentiated retinoblastoma. The presence of synaptophysin, a protein found in neuroendocrine tumors, further supports the diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medulloblastoma: Although medulloblastoma, a neuroendocrine tumor of the cerebellum, can also show synaptophysin positivity and similar rosettes, it does not present with leukocoria or an intraocular mass. This tumor typically occurs in the brain, not the eye.

 

Option B. Retinal detachment: Retinal detachment is a condition where the retina separates from its underlying layer but does not involve tumor formation or the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Leukocoria might be seen in severe cases, but synaptophysin positivity is not associated with this condition.

 

Option D. Pinealoblastoma: Pinealoblastoma is a tumor of the pineal gland and may present with neuroendocrine characteristics similar to medulloblastoma, including synaptophysin positivity. However, it does not present with intraocular features like leukocoria or rosettes specific to retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key point to remember is that retinoblastoma presents with leukocoria, an intraocular mass, and characteristic Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on microscopic examination. It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children and should be promptly recognized.

questions.text: What is the most common cause for the appearance shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinoblastoma

 

The image shown here shows leukocoria (white eye reflex).

 

Retinoblastoma:

 

  • Most common eye tumor in children.
  • Rb1 gene located on 13q14 requires both alleles mutated (Knudson’s hypothesis).
  • Rb1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene.
  • Most common presentation is leukocoria.
  • 2nd most common symptom is squint.
  • Clinical Features:

 

i. Quiescent stage:

  • Characterised by Leukocoria which is also known as Amaurotic cat’s eye appearance, convergent squint, defective vision and nystagmus (seen in bilateral cases).
  • Ophthalmoscopically, endophytic retinoblastoma gives “cottage cheese appearance” whereas exophytic tumor present as exudative retinal detachment.

 

ii. Glaucomatous stage:

  • Presents as severe pain, redness and watering. It may also result in hyphaema or pseudohypopyon (contains tumor cells).

 

iii. Extraocular extension:

  • Globe burst through sclera near limbus and presents as marked proptosis.

 

iv. Distant metastasis:

  • Metastasis of retinoblastoma spread to 
    • Optic nerve via direct extension
    • Pre-auricular lymph nodes via lymphatics
    • Cranial bones via blood
    • Microscopy – Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes.
    • Treatment:
  • Enucleation
  • Chemotherapy→ intra-arterial chemo – melphalan in ophthalmic artery is very successful.
  • VEC is very successful:

V – Vincristine

E – Etoposide

C – Carboplatin

 

Other common causes of leukocoria are-

  • Congenital Cataract
  • Coats disease,
  • Coloboma of Fundus
  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP),
  • Persistent fetal vasculature (PFV)/ Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV)
  • Ocular toxocariasis and toxoplasmosis,
  • Astrocytic hamartoma,
  • Familial exudative vitreoretinopathy (FEVR),
  • Vitreous haemorrhage

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhabdomyosarcoma: This is a malignant tumor of striated muscle but does not typically present with leukocoria.

 

Option C. Congenital cataract: While congenital cataracts can cause leukocoria, retinoblastoma is the most common cause in children.

 

Option D. Congenital glaucoma: This condition presents with symptoms like enlarged cornea, tearing, and photophobia but not with leukocoria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma is the most common cause of leukocoria (white eye reflex) in children. It is a serious condition that requires prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent life-threatening complications.

questions.text: A 1-week-old child was presented with early cataract. He also has refusal to feed, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis. This can be caused due to the deficiency of which enzyme? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase

 

The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of classic galactosemia, a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT). This enzyme deficiency leads to an accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate, which causes toxicity, especially in the liver, kidney, and lens of the eye.

 

The symptoms presented in the question are early cataract, refusal to feed, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis—are typical of galactosemia. The cataract seen in these patients is often described as an "," which is due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens, a metabolite of galactose.

 

 

Galactosemia can be of three types:

 

  • Type 1: Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency (most common and severe form).
  • Type 2: Galactokinase deficiency.
  • Type 3: UDP-galactose-4-epimerase deficiency.

 

Among these, Type 1 galactosemia (GALT deficiency) is responsible for the symptoms described and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. It is not associated with galactose metabolism or the symptoms described, making this an incorrect choice.

 

Option C. Aldose reductase: Aldose reductase converts galactose to galactitol in the lens, contributing to cataract formation in patients with galactosemia. However, the enzyme's deficiency is not the primary cause of the described condition; instead, its action exacerbates the effects of galactosemia.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is involved in the phosphorylation of glucose, not galactose. It plays no direct role in the pathogenesis of galactosemia or the symptoms mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase and presents with early cataracts, feeding difficulties, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis in newborns.

questions.text: Following an accident, a mechanic got injured in the eye. Which of the following is the investigation of choice to rule out intraocular metallic foreign body?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT scan

 

The investigation of choice for any metallic body is CT scan. It can localize foreign bodies as small as 1 mm, as shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging is contraindicated for metallic foreign bodies because the strong magnetic field can move the metal, potentially causing further injury.

 

Option C. PET Scan: Positron Emission Tomography is not suitable for detecting metallic foreign bodies as it is used primarily for metabolic and functional imaging.

 

Option D. Nuclear Radiology: Typically used for other diagnostic purposes, such as bone scans and thyroid imaging, and not for detecting metallic foreign bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A CT scan is the investigation of choice to rule out an intraocular metallic foreign body due to its ability to provide high-resolution images and precisely localize small metallic objects within the eye. MRI is contraindicated due to the risk of movement of the metallic object, and PET scans and nuclear radiology are not appropriate for this type of investigation.

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD with complaints of reduced vision, but on examination, it does not improve with pinhole test. What could be the diagnosis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amblyopia

 

  • Pinhole testing eliminates all light rays except the one passing directly through the nodal point and reaching the fovea, leading to improved visual acuity specifically for refractive errors.
  • Loss of vision that persists even when the refractive errors are corrected, indicates amblyopia.
  • Amblyopia—or lazy eye—is often associated with crossed eyes or is a large difference in the degree of nearsightedness or farsightedness between the two eyes. It occurs due to reduced visual stimulus from the affected eye. It usually develops before age 6 and does not affect side vision. Eyeglasses or contact lenses cannot fully correct the reduced vision caused by amblyopia if vision was not developed within the critical period.

 

Causes & risk factors

  • A high prescription that has gone uncorrected with glasses or contacts.
  • Family history.
  • Premature birth.
  • Developmentally disabled.
  • Eye turn—also referred to as strabismus (one eye turned out or in).
  • Visual deprivation of one eye—congenital cataract, ptosis and/or corneal opacities.
  • Large refractive errors.

 

Symptoms

Symptoms may include noticeably favoring one eye or a tendency to bump into objects on one side. Symptoms are not always obvious.

 

Treatment

Treatment for lazy eye may include a combination of prescription lenses, prisms, vision therapy and eye patching. In vision therapy, patients learn how to use the two eyes together, which helps prevent lazy eye from reoccurring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Astigmatism: A refractive error that typically improves with the pinhole test as it allows the central light rays to focus more accurately on the retina.

 

Option C. Myopia: Nearsightedness that also improves with the pinhole test because it corrects the focusing of light rays.

 

Option D. Hypermetropia: Farsightedness that improves with the pinhole test as it helps focus the light rays directly on the retina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amblyopia is characterized by reduced vision that does not improve with the pinhole test or corrective lenses. It results from inadequate visual stimulus during the critical period of visual development and requires treatment such as prescription lenses, vision therapy, or eye patching to improve visual acuity.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with white pupillary reflex in the right eye. CT scan shows a cauliflower like growth arising from the retina with calcifications within. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

Retinoblastoma:

 

  • Most common eye tumor in children.
  • Rb1 gene located on 13q14, requires both alleles mutation (Knudson’s hypothesis).
  • Rb1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene.
  • Most common presentation is leukocoria.
  • 2nd most common symptom is squint.
  • Clinical Features:

i) Quiescent stage:

  • Characterized by Leukocoria which is also known as Amaurotic cat’s eye appearance, convergent squint, defective vision and nystagmus (seen in bilateral cases).
  • Ophthalmoscopically, endophytic retinoblastoma gives “cottage cheese appearance” whereas exophytic tumor present as exudative retinal detachment.

 

ii) Glaucomatous stage:

  • Presents as severe pain, redness and watering. It may also result in hyphaema or pseudohypopyon (contains tumor cells).

 

iii) Extraocular extension:

  • Globe burst through sclera near limbus and presents as marked proptosis.

 

iv) Distant metastasis:

  • Metastasis of retinoblastoma spread to 
    • Optic nerve via direct extension
    • Pre-auricular lymph nodes via lymphatics
    • Cranial bones via blood
  • Microscopy – Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes
  • Treatment:
    • Enucleation
    • Chemotherapy→ intra-arterial chemo – melphalan in ophthalmic artery is very successful.
    • VEC regime is very successful:

 

V – Vincristine

E – Etoposide

C – Carboplatin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal detachment: Typically presents with visual disturbances such as floaters, flashes of light, and a shadow or curtain over part of the visual field. It does not typically present with a cauliflower-like growth or calcifications on a CT scan.

 

Option B. Keratitis: Involves inflammation of the cornea, presenting with pain, redness, and blurred vision, not a white pupillary reflex or retinal growth.

 

Option D. Pterygium: A benign growth on the conjunctiva that can extend onto the cornea. It does not cause leukocoria or a cauliflower-like growth on a CT scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma is the most common eye tumor in children and can be identified by leukocoria and a characteristic cauliflower-like growth with calcifications on imaging.

 

Other common causes of leukocoria are-

 

  • Coats disease
  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP)
  • Persistent fetal vasculature (PFV)
  • Ocular toxocariasis and toxoplasmosis
  • Astrocytic hamartoma
  • Familial exudative vitreoretinopathy (FEVR)
  • Vitreous haemorrhage

questions.text: What is the best test to diagnose Wilson’s disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatic copper estimation

 

Wilson’s disease is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and other tissues, leading to hepato-lenticular degeneration. The most definitive and gold standard diagnostic test for Wilson’s disease is hepatic copper estimation, typically performed through a liver biopsy. This test directly measures the copper content in liver tissue, confirming the disease's diagnosis.

 

In addition, the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring, which is a copper deposit around the cornea, is a commonly seen ophthalmic feature of the disease. Another important ophthalmologic finding in Wilson's disease is the sunflower cataract, which occurs in the lens. These signs are crucial for diagnosing the hepato-lenticular degeneration associated with Wilson's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine copper: This test measures the amount of copper excreted in the urine, which can be elevated in Wilson’s disease but is not definitive for diagnosis. It is often used to monitor treatment response rather than as a primary diagnostic tool.

 

Option B. Serum ceruloplasmin: Wilson’s disease is associated with low levels of ceruloplasmin, a copper-carrying protein. However, low ceruloplasmin levels alone are not specific to Wilson’s disease and can be seen in other conditions, making it a supportive but not definitive test.

 

Option C. Serum copper: Although serum copper levels may be low in Wilson’s disease due to decreased ceruloplasmin, free serum copper may be elevated. This test is not reliable for diagnosing Wilson’s disease and is better used as part of a comprehensive evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:


Hepatic copper estimation via liver biopsy is the gold standard test for diagnosing Wilson’s disease, providing a direct measure of copper accumulation in the liver.

questions.text: A patient presented with sudden, painful diminution of vision, difficulty in vision in light, and circumferential congestion with hypopyon as shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute Anterior Uveitis

 

Acute Anterior Uveitis is an inflammatory condition affecting the uveal tract of the eye, particularly the anterior segment. It is characterized by the sudden onset of pain, redness, photophobia (difficulty seeing in bright light), and diminished vision. A key finding in this condition is the presence of hypopyon, which is the accumulation of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, settling at the bottom.

 

Key clinical signs of Acute Anterior Uveitis includes:

 

1. Hypopyon - The accumulation of white cells (pus) in the anterior chamber.

 

 

2. Circumferential congestion (ciliary flush) - Redness around the corneal edge.

 

 

3. Miotic (small) pupil - A constricted pupil which is not typical in other conditions listed.

 

4. Posterior synechiae, which is an adhesion between the iris and the lens. When attempting to dilate a pupil with posterior synechiae, a festooned (flower-shaped) pupil may result.

 

5. On the corneal endothelium, keratic precipitates (KPs), which are cellular aggregates with protein deposits, are a pathognomonic feature of uveitis.

 

 

6. Painful, diminished vision - Common in inflammatory eye conditions like uveitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Congestive Glaucoma: This condition involves elevated intraocular pressure, severe eye pain, and blurred vision. However, the pupil in acute glaucoma is usually mid-dilated and sluggish, not miotic, and hypopyon is not a feature of glaucoma.

 

Option C. Acute Conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis primarily affects the conjunctiva, causing redness, irritation, and discharge. Hypopyon is not seen in conjunctivitis, and the condition is not typically associated with severe pain or vision changes seen in uveitis.

 

Option D. Episcleritis: Episcleritis is an inflammation of the episclera, leading to redness and mild discomfort. It usually affects one quadrant and is rarely associated with hypopyon or significant visual symptoms. The pupil size remains normal, and there is no severe pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Anterior Uveitis is characterized by a painful red eye, circumcorneal congestion, hypopyon, and a miotic pupil, distinguishing it from other ocular conditions.

questions.text: In a child with difference in visual acuity between two eyes, what is the cause of persistent decreased vision even after correction of refractive error? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anisometropic Amblyopia

 

  • Amblyopia refers to unilateral, or rarely bilateral, decrease in best corrected visual acuity (VA) caused by vision deprivation and/or abnormal binocular interaction, for which there is no identifiable pathology of the eye or visual pathway.
  • A diagnosis of amblyopia is made when a difference in best corrected VA of two Snellen lines or more is present, in the absence of an organic lesion.
  • ‘Crowding’ phenomenon: VA in amblyopia is usually better when reading single letters than letters in a row. It occurs to a certain extent in normal individuals but is more marked in amblyopes.

 

Causes & risk factors

  • A high prescription that has gone uncorrected with glasses or contacts.
  • Family history.
  • Premature birth.
  • Developmentally disabled.
  • Eye turn—also referred to as strabismus (one eye turned out or in).
  • Visual deprivation of one eye—congenital cataract, ptosis and/or corneal opacities.
  • Large refractive errors.

 

Symptoms

  • Symptoms may include noticeably favoring one eye or a tendency to bump into objects on one side. Symptoms are not always obvious.
  • It usually develops before age 6 and does not affect side vision.

 

Treatment

  • In vision therapy, patients learn how to use the two eyes together, which helps prevent lazy eye from reoccurring.
  • Eyeglasses or contact lenses cannot fully correct the reduced vision caused by amblyopia if vision was not developed within the critical period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anisometropia: Refers to a difference in refractive error between the two eyes but does not explain persistent decreased vision after correction.

 

Option C. Refractive error: Simply refers to issues like myopia, hypermetropia, or astigmatism, which are correctable with lenses and do not cause persistent decreased vision after correction.

 

Option D. Aniseikonia: A condition where there is a significant difference in the perceived size of images between the two eyes, which is not the primary cause of persistent decreased vision after refractive error correction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropic amblyopia is the cause of persistent decreased vision in a child with a difference in visual acuity between the two eyes, even after correction of the refractive error. It results from abnormal visual development due to the brain favoring one eye over the other during the critical period of visual maturation.

 

Additional Information

questions.text: A child presented with hydrocephalus, intracranial calcification, and bilateral chorioretinitis. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital Toxoplasmosis


Congenital toxoplasmosis is classically associated with the triad of hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis. This triad is often remembered as "C3" where C represents chorioretinitis, calcifications (intracranial), and hydrocephalus (cephalus).

 

Toxoplasma gondii infection in utero can cause these characteristic findings, and they are critical for the diagnosis. These symptoms result from the parasite's effect on the brain and eyes, leading to fluid accumulation (hydrocephalus), calcified lesions in the brain, and inflammation of the choroid and retina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital Syphilis:  The classical triad of congenital syphilis is represented by "INH" - Interstitial Keratitis, Neurosensory Deafness, and Hutchinson's teeth.

 

 

Option C. Congenital Rubella: The triad associated with congenital rubella includes cataracts, heart disease (often patent ductus arteriosus or other cardiac defects), and neurosensory deafness, summarized as "CHD" (Cataract, Heart Disease, Deafness). It does not involve hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, or chorioretinitis.

 

 

Option D. Neisseria gonorrhea: Neisseria gonorrhea is a bacterial infection that typically does not present with a triad of symptoms and is unrelated to congenital infections leading to hydrocephalus, intracranial calcification, or chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective:


The classical triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis, which are key findings for diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of blindness in children?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of blindness in children, particularly in developing countries. Vitamin A is essential for the maintenance of healthy vision, immune function, and epithelial integrity. Deficiency in this vitamin can lead to a spectrum of ocular manifestations, starting with night blindness and progressing to xerophthalmia and keratomalacia, which can result in irreversible blindness.

 

Key Points:

  • Night blindness: One of the earliest signs of vitamin A deficiency, where the child has difficulty seeing in low light conditions.
  • Xerophthalmia: Characterized by dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea.
  • Keratomalacia: Severe vitamin A deficiency can lead to softening and ulceration of the cornea, ultimately resulting in blindness if not treated promptly.

 

Prevalence and Public Health Impact:

  • Developing countries: Vitamin A deficiency remains a significant public health issue, contributing to a high prevalence of childhood blindness.
  • India: The prevalence of blindness (visual acuity less than 3/60) is 0.36%, and visual impairment (visual acuity less than 6/18) is 2.55%.

 

Prevention and Treatment:

  • Dietary intake: Ensuring adequate intake of vitamin A through diet (rich in green leafy vegetables, dairy products, and liver).
  • Supplementation: In regions with high prevalence, vitamin A supplementation programs are implemented to prevent deficiency.
  • Public health initiatives: Programs aimed at improving nutrition and health education to address vitamin A deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataract: While cataracts are the most common cause of blindness in adults, they are not the leading cause in children.

 

Option B. Glaucoma: Although glaucoma can cause blindness, it is not the most common cause in children.

 

Option D. Refractive Error: Refractive errors can lead to visual impairment but are usually correctable with glasses or contact lenses and are not the leading cause of blindness in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of blindness in children, particularly in developing countries. It leads to a range of ocular problems, from night blindness to keratomalacia, and can result in permanent blindness if not addressed through proper nutrition and public health measures.

questions.text: 2 hours after watching a movie, a patient presented with eye ache and difficulty in vision. The first line of management must be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mannitol + Pilocarpine

 

The scenario described is indicative of an acute angle-closure glaucoma attack, which commonly occurs when a person with a shallow anterior chamber enters a dark environment, such as a movie theater. In the dark, the pupil dilates, and the iris moves peripherally, leading to blockage of the trabecular meshwork and subsequently increased intraocular pressure (IOP). This condition requires urgent management to prevent damage to the optic nerve.

 

Mannitol, a hyperosmotic agent, is administered to quickly reduce the vitreous volume by drawing fluid out of the eye, thereby decreasing IOP. This reduction in vitreous volume allows the lens and iris to move backward, alleviating the blockage of the trabecular meshwork. After the IOP is reduced, Pilocarpine, a miotic agent, is given to constrict the pupil and prevent further angle closure, helping to maintain the IOP at a safer level.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mannitol + Moxifloxacin: Moxifloxacin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections. It has no role in the management of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Option C. Mannitol + Atropine: Atropine is a mydriatic agent that dilates the pupil, which would worsen the condition by increasing angle closure. Therefore, it is contraindicated in this scenario.

 

Option D. Mannitol + lubricating eye drops: Lubricating eye drops only provide surface moisture and have no effect on intraocular pressure or the underlying mechanism of angle closure, making them ineffective in this emergency situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line management of acute angle-closure glaucoma involves the use of Mannitol to reduce intraocular pressure followed by Pilocarpine to constrict the pupil and prevent further angle obstruction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female is diagnosed to have paralysis of all extraocular muscles except the lateral rectus. A lesion in which of the following locations can result in such a situation?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Midbrain

 

The extraocular muscles responsible for eye movements are innervated by three cranial nerves: the oculomotor nerve (CN III), the trochlear nerve (CN IV), and the abducent nerve (CN VI).

 

  • Nerve Supply of Extraocular Muscles
    • Oculomotor nerve (CN III)—medial, superior and lateral recti; inferior oblique
    • Trochlear nerve (CN IV)—superior oblique
    • Abducent nerve (CN VI)—lateral rectus
  • The 3rd and 4th nerve nucleus lie in the mid brain. Hence, a midbrain lesion can result in paralysis of all muscles except lateral rectus.
  • Cranial nerve nuclei and their location:
    • CN III, IV: Midbrain
    • CN IX,X,XI,XII: Medulla
    • CN V,VI,VII,VIII: Pons

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper medulla: Lesions in this area would affect the cranial nerves associated with the medulla, which are CN IX, X, XI, and XII, and would not explain the paralysis of extraocular muscles.

 

Option B. Pons: Lesions in the pons would affect CN V, VI, VII, and VIII. While CN VI (abducent) is located here, a lesion affecting the pons would typically affect the lateral rectus muscle as well.

 

Option C. Lower medulla: Similar to the upper medulla, lesions here would affect CN IX, X, XI, and XII, not the extraocular muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the midbrain can result in paralysis of all extraocular muscles except the lateral rectus due to the involvement of the nuclei of the oculomotor nerve (CN III) and trochlear nerve (CN IV), which are responsible for innervating these muscles. The lateral rectus muscle, innervated by the abducent nerve (CN VI), is spared as its nucleus is located in the pons.

questions.text: What is the finding shown in the figure characteristic of? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Viral keratitis

 

The figure shows dendritic ulcers that are seen in viral keratitis.

They are irregular, linear branching ulcers with knobbed ends and reduced corneal sensations.

 

Viral Ulcer

 

It can be caused by Herpes simplex virus (most common), Varicella zoster virus and Adenovirus. Pathognomic feature of viral corneal ulcer is decrease in corneal sensations.

 

Herpes simplex keratitis

 

Man is the only natural host for this DNA virus. It can be the following types:

 

  1. Primary herpes: It is usually caused by primary infection in non-immunized children. The features include vesicular skin lesions, follicular conjunctivitis or keratitis (usually affect epithelium only).
  2. Secondary herpes: It is due to reactivation of a dormant (latent) virus in the trigeminal nerve ganglion. It causes decrease in corneal sensations. It can affect either the epithelium or the stroma.

 

  • Epithelial keratitis: It manifests as dendritic ulcer or geographical ulcer (large ‘amoeboid’ ulcer). Steroids cause progression of dendritic ulcer into geographical ulcer, so, they are contraindicated. The treatment is done with 3% acyclovir ointment and mechanical debridement.
  • Stromal keratitis: It manifests as disciform keratitis (disc shaped ulcer with a surrounding Wessley immune ring formed due to delayed hypersensitivity to HSV antigen) or diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis (due to active viral invasion and tissue destruction). The treatment is steroid drops with acyclovir 3%.

 

 

Dendritic corneal ulcer due to recurrent keratitis by Herpes Simplex Virus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal keratitis: Typically presents with a feathery-edged corneal ulcer, satellite lesions, and hypopyon. It is not characterized by dendritic ulcers.

 

Option C. Bacterial keratitis: Presents with a round, well-demarcated ulcer, often with hypopyon and severe pain. Dendritic patterns are not seen.

 

Option D. Acanthamoeba keratitis: Typically presents with severe pain, perineural infiltrates, and ring infiltrates. It is associated with contact lens use and does not present with dendritic ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dendritic ulcers are a hallmark of viral keratitis, particularly Herpes simplex keratitis, and are characterized by their irregular, branching pattern and reduced corneal sensations.

questions.text: A child presents to an ophthalmologist with the complaint of blurred vision while trying to see the blackboard in the classroom. The doctor prescribes him concave lenses. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myopia

 

Myopia, or nearsightedness, is a common refractive error where distant objects appear blurry because their images are focused in front of the retina. This condition is corrected with concave (minus) lenses, which help focus the light rays directly onto the retina, improving distance vision.

 

Myopia

  • When the image of distant objects focuses in front of the retina in the unaccommodated eye, the eye is myopic, or near-sighted.
  • Axial myopia: The error when the eye is longer than average. (For each additional millimetre of axial length, the eye is approximately 3 dioptres more myopic.)
  • Curvature myopia or Refractive myopia: The error when the refractive elements are more refractive than average.
  • As the object is brought closer than 6 m, the image moves closer to the retina and comes into sharper focus. The point reached where the image is most sharply focused on the retina is called the “far point.” One may estimate the extent of myopia by calculating the reciprocal of the far point. Thus, a far point of 0.25 m would suggest a 4-diopter minus lens correction for distance.
  • The myopic person has the advantage of being able to read at the far point without glasses even at the age of presbyopia.
  • A high degree of myopia results in greater susceptibility to degenerative retinal changes, including retinal detachment.
  • Concave spherical (minus) lenses are used to correct the image in myopia. These lenses move the image back to the retina.

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. Hyperopia

  • Hyperopia (hypermetropia, farsightedness) is the state in which the unaccommodated eye would focus the image behind the retina.
  • It may be due to reduced axial length (axial hyperopia), as occurs in certain congenital disorders, or reduced refractive error (refractive hyperopia), as exemplified by aphakia.
  • Hyperopia is a more difficult concept to explain than myopia. The term “farsighted” contributes to the difficulty, as does the prevalent misconception among laymen that presbyopia is farsightedness and that one who sees well far away is farsighted.
  • If hyperopia is not too great, a young person may obtain a sharp distant image by accommodating, as a normal eye would to read. The young hyperopic person may also make a sharp near image by accommodating more—or much more than one without hyperopia. This extra effort may result in eye fatigue that is more severe for near work. The degree of hyperopia a person may have without symptoms is variable. However, the amount decreases with age as presbyopia (decrease in ability to accommodate) increases. Three dioptres of hyperopia might be tolerated in a teenager but will require glasses later, even though the hyperopia has not increased.
  • If the hyperopia is too high, the eye may be unable to correct the image by accommodation. The hyperopia that cannot be corrected by accommodation is termed manifest hyperopia. This is one of the causes of deprivation amblyopia in children and can be bilateral.

 

 

 

 

Option C. Astigmatism: This condition results from an irregular curvature of the cornea or lens, leading to blurred vision at all distances. It is corrected with cylindrical lenses rather than simple concave lenses.

 

Option D. Night blindness: This is a condition characterized by poor vision in low light conditions, often due to vitamin A deficiency or retinal disorders. It is not related to refractive errors and is not corrected with concave lenses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myopia, or nearsightedness, causes difficulty seeing distant objects clearly. It is diagnosed when vision improves with the use of concave lenses, which correct the focal point of distant images onto the retina. This condition is distinct from hypermetropia, astigmatism, and night blindness, each requiring different treatments and corrections.
